awd_titl_txt: P2C2: Collaborative Research: The consumption rate of a CO2 pulse: Lessons from the middle Miocene
awd_abstract_narration:
As human activity has already produced atmospheric carbon dioxide concentrations that have surpassed the highest levels known during of the past three million years of Earth history, it is critical for society to better understand the fate of atmospheric carbon dioxide produced by fossil fuel burning and other human activities.  More accurate projections of future climate scenarios will require a more detailed understanding of how fast natural processes can remove from Earth's atmosphere the pulse of carbon dioxide that is being produced by society in the industrial era. Models of these processes predict a long tail of the pulse of human-produced carbon dioxide, suggesting that this carbon will have a long-term impact on our climate and society.  As these processes play out over relatively long timescales, such predictions can be verified by looking to the geological record of past events. This project will provide a high-resolution reconstruction of how an ancient natural pulse of carbon dioxide injected into the atmosphere was neutralized by the Earth system in the geological past. As such, this study will provide important perspective from the past on the present rate at which atmospheric carbon can be taken up by natural processes, and hence help Earth scientists make more accurate projections of future climate change.  The researchers will also work with a Geoscience summer residence camp for high school students and non-science major undergraduate students will participate in experiential learning in the field on the impact of climate change. Both activities will contribute to bringing students with diverse backgrounds into STEM and geoscience career paths.
This research will evaluate the evolution of atmospheric CO2 on decadal timescales following a rapid pulse of large amounts of carbon dioxide injected into the atmosphere during volcanic eruptions that was part of the Columbia River Basalt Group in the US Pacific Northwest.  At the same time as these eruptions and nearby in northern Idaho, an ancient lake (Miocene Lake Clarkia) was formed when basalt flows presumably dammed a local drainage system.  Sediments that began to accumulate in the newly formed Lake Clarkia preserve a history of these events in the geological record that can be used to evaluate, in high-resolution, the evolution of the spike of atmospheric CO2 concentrations that resulted from the volcanic eruptions.  The researchers will use micro-XRF scanning of elemental distributions to focus their study on the unoxidized, varve-like sediments.  They will reconstruct the evolution of this natural pulse of CO2 using the properties of stomatal pores in fossil leaves preserved in the sediments, combined with information from the stable isotopes of carbon preserved in the fossil organic matter.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This highly interdisciplinary project focused on the investigation of ancient atmospheric CO2 levels, its relations with regional volcanic activities, and global carbon cycle and climate change during the middle Miocene global warming period and its implications for the near future climate change caused by the massive amounts of anthropogenic CO2 emissions. Utilizing the unique material preserved in the lacustrine deposit in Clarkia, Idaho, some of our targeted questions are (1) what is the exact age of the Clarkia lacustrine deposits and how it related to the eruption of the Columbia River Basalt? (2) what are the sedimentary rates of the deposit and what are the tempo resolution of the lake sequence? (3) what were the levels of atmospheric CO2 during the time of the Clarkia deposition and what are their temporal fluctuations in relation to temperature changes? (4) what are the impact of Clarkia CO2 pulse to global climate and its implications for the rapidly increasing anthropogenic CO2?

As reflected in our high quality publications and numerous conference presentations, this work resulted in a refined chronology and associated sedimentation rates for the Clarkia deposit and developed a method for the preparation of clearing leaf cuticles that allow precise measurements of stomatal parameters for the reconstruction of ancient CO2 via the Franks model. We further evaluated other plant leaf based CO2 reconstruction proxies, such as the stomatal index method. We pinpointed the age of the Clarkia lacustrine deposit using the currently available multiple dating technologies. A precise age of 15.98 Ma ties the Clarkia sediment and fossil deposit to the eruption of the Columbia River Basalt volcanism that is believed to have released large amount of CO2 to the atmosphere and caused the Miocene Climate Optimum, a climate condition that we are rapidly approaching with the current rate of anthropogenic CO2 emission. By applying the micro-X-ray scanning technology that was previously used for ocean drilling cores, we settled a long-standing debate regarding the temporal duration of the deposited lake sediments, establishing the annual rhythmic deposit. By doing so, we confined the entire lake sequence within 1,000 years ? framing a millennium time window during a critical time of the Earth history for future high resolution analysis.

The products of this work also include the development of new clear leaf cuticle method and a test for the range of variations of these parameters to evaluate their impact on the output of the Franks model in key conifer fossils, such as Metasequoia, Sequoia, and Taxodium, that are commonly used for paleoenvironmental studies. We applied the new experimental approach and parameterization to reconstruct Clarkia middle Miocene CO2 that yielded ~500 ppm values for the middle Miocene warming time. These results laid out a foundation on which ongoing research on climate modeling, high-resolution proxy work, and climate change education programs are being conducted. This award also supported 4 Bryant undergraduate students for hands-on research. It further developed a field based experiential learning program on climate change for both undergraduate and graduate programs and used Clarkia as an outdoor laboratory to attract minority, woman-identified, and international students to climate change research. Based upon this project, an onsite workshop on ?Climate Change: Facts, forces, and future? was joined organized by Bryant University and Texas A&M University, involving research scientists, faculty, and both undergraduate and graduate students.

In summary, this award allowed us to answer some key questions regarding the temporal and mode of the exceptional Clarkia deposit and its chronological relations with the Columbia River Basalts that emitted significant amount of greenhouse gases. This project also allowed us to improve both technology and parameterization for CO2 reconstruction for the Franks model. In addition, it offered us a unique opportunity to enhance experiential learning education program focusing on climate change for training both undergraduate and graduate students in interdisciplinary research in the field and in the laboratory.
